stories.headline: Real ID takeoff relatively smooth at SFO
stories.summary: The implementation of the security-enhanced Real ID at San Francisco International Airport has proceeded with relative ease despite initial concerns. Federal officials required travelers to have Real ID to board flights or enter certain government buildings, but the transition was smooth with no significant disruptions, aided by announcements and notices throughout the terminal.

stories.headline: Dems rip Travis detention proposal
stories.summary: Two Bay Area Democratic House members criticized U.S. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth's plan to use Travis Air Force Base in Fairfield as an immigrant detention center, claiming it would harm military readiness and represented unnecessary militarization of immigration enforcement. Homeland security officials have evaluated the potential military and immigration impacts of the proposal.

stories.headline: ‘PEACE BE WITH YOU’
stories.summary: Robert Prevost, a Chicago-born missionary and former minister in Peru, has become the first American pope in Catholic Church history, taking the name Pope Leo XIV. His election as the 267th pontiff emphasizes peace, dialogue, and missionary evangelization, as well as a return to some traditional aspects of the papacy while honoring Pope Francis's approach.

stories.headline: Union slams SFMOMA’s layoffs amid cost cutting
stories.summary: The San Francisco Museum of Modern Art laid off 29 employees, triggering backlash from its workers and their representatives, who criticized the decision as unnecessary and harmful. The layoffs represent about 7.5% of the workforce and largely affect union members. The union called for a protest against the museum's decision to prioritize budget cuts over retaining frontline staff.

stories.headline: 'Habemus papam': New pope elected
stories.summary: Cardinal Robert Prevost was named Pope Leo XIV, becoming the first pope from the United States, announced amidst great celebration in Rome. His election marks a new era for the 1.4 billion Roman Catholics worldwide. After a white smoke signal from the chimney of the Sistine Chapel, the cardinal appeared on the balcony of St. Peter's Basilica to greet the crowd and declare, 'we have a pope'.

stories.headline: Four walks and a homer make Borba a force in Longhorn win
stories.summary: In a sports highlight, Borba significantly contributed to the Longhorns' victory through four walks and a home run during their latest game. His performance was vital to the team's success and is noted as a key force behind the win.

stories.headline: Activist: Citizen children removed
stories.summary: Two U.S. citizen children living in Austin and their mother, who is an immigrant without legal status, were deported to Mexico. Denisse Parra Vargas, along with her 9-, 5-, and 4-year-old children, were detained and moved to a facility in Pflugerville before deportation. Local activists and the Mexican Consulate confirmed the removal, noting that Parra Vargas had an active deportation order. Activists and lawyers expressed concern over the treatment and separation of families amid ongoing immigration crackdowns.

stories.headline: This Boise neighborhood was caught off guard by a 2016 fire. It won’t be again
stories.summary: A wildfire in 2016 burned 2,500 acres near Table Rock in Boise, exposing unpreparedness of nearby neighborhoods, which lacked emergency notifications and kept residents unaware until it was nearly too late. Residents, through a neighborhood association, have since formed Municipal Emergency Safety Actions (MESA) to better prepare for future emergencies. The team disseminates information and provides evacuation plans together with local authorities to improve safety.

stories.headline: Boise adds two official flags in latest jab at new law
stories.summary: The Boise City Council voted to add the Pride flag as an official city flag to oppose a new state law that bans flying most flags from government property with exceptions. The new law was seen as targeting Pride and other official flags. During the city council meeting, supporters and opponents expressed strong opinions. The change means Boise now has three official flags, including the National Donate Life Month banner, as a statement against the restrictive legislation.

stories.headline: Jury finds man in viral police incident guilty
stories.summary: Samson Allen was found guilty of charges including resisting arrest and obstructing justice related to an incident where he pressed his knee to a police officer's neck. The jury reviewed video evidence captured by police body cameras and patrol cars. The case garnered viral attention online and involved an internal review by the department. Allen was convicted based on the combined evidence and testimonies in court.

stories.headline: Kohberger’s family allowed to attend trial, judge says
stories.summary: Bryan Kohberger's immediate family will be allowed to attend the entirety of his upcoming capital murder trial. The decision follows two orders from 4th District Judge Steven Hippler, who allowed members of the defense's request to have the family present as their testimony is unlikely to affect the prosecution's case. The judge also partly granted the prosecution’s request to conduct a mental health exam of Kohberger, who has autism spectrum disorder and other conditions.

stories.headline: Vatican announces first US pope: Leo XIV
stories.summary: Cardinal Robert Francis Prevost has been elected as the new pope of the United States, taking the name Pope Leo XIV. He is the first US-born pope and the second American pope after Pope Francis. Leo XIV, formerly known as Cardinal Prevost, addressed the crowd in St. Peter's Square and emphasized unity and building bridges. President Donald Trump congratulated him on his historic election as the first American Pope.

stories.headline: City faces tough budget decisions
stories.summary: Dallas faces a $6.5 million revenue shortfall well into the fiscal year, prompting city officials to consider departmental budget cuts. Dallas City Manager Kim Tolbert warned that the city is in for a painful summer as concerns arise over meeting current fiscal obligations. Officials are working to prioritize services and programs by creating an inventory of needs. The shortfall is partly due to declining property tax bills and other economic pressures impacting city revenues.

stories.headline: ‘Peace be with all of you’ Chicago-born priest is first American to lead Catholic Church
stories.summary: Cardinal Robert Prevost, a Chicago-born missionary who spent his career ministering in Peru, has been elected as Pope Leo XIV, the first American to lead the Catholic Church. Prevost, 69, assumed the powerful position in the Vatican, signaling a moment of hope and renewal for the church. His appointment was celebrated by North Texas’ Catholic community, who are hopeful that the new pontiff will guide the church with faith, truth, and charity.

stories.headline: 'PEACE BE WITH YOU'
stories.summary: Robert Prevost, a 69-year-old Chicago-born missionary and member of the Augustinian religious order, has become the first pope from the United States in Catholic Church history. Upon his election as Pope Leo XIV, Prevost addressed the crowd from St Peter's Basilica at the Vatican, emphasizing a message of peace and missionary evangelization. He overcame cultural and language taboos to ascend to the papacy, bringing broad experience from missionary work in Peru and fluency in multiple languages.

stories.headline: Traffic plan limits parking on beach for Jeep Weekend
stories.summary: Galveston County has approved a traffic control plan restricting parking on Bolivar Peninsula beaches during Jeep Weekend from May 16 to 18. The plan excludes a 6.25-mile portion of the beach from full closure but disallows parking for non-residents, aiming to manage beach access and traffic. A spokesperson confirmed the county's intention to limit traffic within the event area to maintain order and ensure safety during the popular annual event.

stories.headline: Abbott calls out Dems in push for bail crackdown
stories.summary: Texas Governor Greg Abbott signed a significant bail crackdown law aimed at limiting bail for defendants accused of violent offenses. Abbott's signature follows ongoing confrontations with House Democrats, who oppose the effort. Abbott framed the measure as a bipartisan issue responding to public safety concerns. Negotiations continue in the Texas House, with Abbott pressing for continued Democratic support as the bill advances through the legislative process.

stories.headline: Kansas City debates renaming Troost Avenue to Truth Avenue
stories.summary: There is ongoing discussion about renaming Troost Avenue in Kansas City to Truth Avenue. Although the name change is unlikely to happen soon, the debate follows a previous attempt by Chris Goode to rename the street to address its controversial 19th Century history involving a slaveholder. For the second consecutive year, Mayor Quinton Lucas blocked the measure in City Council meetings, highlighting the complexity of changing street names tied to historical legacies.

stories.headline: Kansas AG sues trans rights group for allegedly diverting funds
stories.summary: Kansas Attorney General Kris Kobach filed a civil lawsuit against a Johnson County-based transgender advocacy group, accusing its executive director of diverting funds and using more than $11,000 for personal benefit. The lawsuit follows an urgent Facebook request for donations after a young trans adult had to pay a traffic ticket. The group had received contributions but now faces legal action to address alleged financial misconduct.

stories.headline: Vatican announces first US pope: Leo XIV
stories.summary: Cardinal Robert Francis Prevost from the United States has been elected as the new pope, taking the name Leo XIV. He is the first US and second American pope, succeeding Pope Francis from Argentina. The announcement was made after the traditional papal election process concluded in Vatican Square, where thousands awaited the first public confirmation as smoke signals indicated the election of the new pope. Leo XIV is expected to lead the Catholic Church moving forward.

stories.headline: Some parents seek school transfers over cancer fears
stories.summary: Cory Brown is concerned that the Liberty school her children attend is causing community fears after students were diagnosed with breast cancer near the school. Despite requests, the family was denied a transfer to another school. The Star has requested transfer forms from Warren Hills, but parents' transfer requests citing health concerns have been denied, highlighting the difficulties parents face when trying to protect their children's health in school settings.

stories.headline: NTSB: Aircraft was just inspected
stories.summary: The NTSB reported that the six-seater Cessna 310 plane that crashed shortly after takeoff from Boca Raton Airport on April 11 had been recently inspected during its first flight after an annual inspection. The crash resulted in the deaths of all three occupants and injured one person on the ground.

stories.headline: Maple Leafs 2-0 vs. Panthers as playoff series heads to Florida
stories.summary: The Maple Leafs secured a 2-0 lead against the Panthers in their playoff series, which is now heading to Florida for the next games. The team's strong performance puts them in a favorable position as the series continues.

stories.headline: DeSantis slams GOP plan to cut sales tax
stories.summary: Governor Ron DeSantis criticized a proposed state sales tax cut, arguing that it would jeopardize initiatives to reduce property taxes. Speaking at an event in Tampa, he emphasized the importance of maintaining property tax relief and suggested that the proposed tax cut would not benefit Canadian tourists as claimed.

stories.headline: 'Habemus papam': New pope elected
stories.summary: Thousands celebrated as Cardinal Robert Prevost was named Pope Leo XIV, succeeding Pope Francis. The election took place in the Room of Tears where the 267th pope was announced with the historic words 'Habemus papam,' meaning 'we have a pope.' Leo XIV is noted as the first pope to hail from the United States and was considered a wild card in the election process.

stories.headline: A historic first: a US pope
stories.summary: Robert Prevost became the first US-born pope, taking the papacy as Leo XIV. A Chicago native who lived decades in Peru, he is known as the 'Latin Yankee' for his pastoral work among marginalized communities. His rise marks a significant moment for a divided Catholic Church seeking unity and confronting sex abuse crises.

stories.headline: With 'brilliant lawyers,' Trump keeps options open on upholding Constitution
stories.summary: President Trump expressed confidence in his legal team as he dodged questions about his aggressive executive actions. While declining to offer specific answers on upholding the Constitution, Trump acknowledged having lawyers who work for him and intend to follow the Supreme Court's lead.

stories.headline: NIH cuts felt far beyond schools
stories.summary: The Trump administration cut $1.8 billion in research grants between Feb. 28 and April 8, affecting nearly 700 specific health-related projects. This includes funding for cancer, heart disease, diabetes, suicide prevention, and other biomedical research funded by the National Institutes of Health. Experts warn the cuts will impair advances in health research and patient care.

stories.headline: Autism community divided on RFK Jr.
stories.summary: Gianna Hitsos and Patrick Trainor represent differing perspectives within the autism community on Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s push to find a 'cause' and 'cure' for autism. Some see value in his views, while others warn they are dangerous and unscientific. The debate reflects a deep division about how to address autism and the community’s relationship with public health officials.

stories.headline: 'Habemus papam': New pope elected
stories.summary: Cardinal Robert Prevost, newly named Pope Leo XIV, has become the first pope to hail from the United States, marking a historic moment for the Catholic Church. Thousands cheered as he emerged on the balcony of St. Peter's Basilica at the Vatican after the 133 voting cardinals chose him to succeed Pope Francis. This election represents a new era for the world's 1.4 billion Roman Catholics, emphasizing greater openness and reform.

stories.headline: Voter registration problem
stories.summary: Secretary of State Adrian Fontes is seeking legal guidance on a glitch affecting more than 200,000 voters. This issue impacts voter registration accuracy and could affect upcoming elections, prompting urgent attention to resolve the problem and ensure all eligible voters are properly registered.

stories.headline: Power incident questioned
stories.summary: Regulators are investigating an electric utility's decision to cut power to an 82-year-old woman. The incident has raised questions about the appropriateness and consequences of the utility's actions, with authorities looking into the matter to ensure proper protocols were followed and to protect vulnerable customers.

stories.headline: Heap takes heat over plan to mail unsolicited ballots
stories.summary: Maricopa County Recorder Justin Heap is under scrutiny from his own party for plans to mail ballots to some voters who haven't signed up to receive them in the upcoming July 15 primary. The county attorney now says this plan could be illegal, spreading concern about voter fraud or confusion given the rural nature of some precincts. Despite this, the Recorder's Office intends to proceed. GOP leaders express worry that this may complicate power struggles and election responsibilities.

stories.headline: Valley Catholics delighted at naming of U.S.-born pope
stories.summary: The bells of St. Mary's Basilica in Phoenix rang as parishioners celebrated the naming of the first U.S.-born pope, Cardinal Robert Prevost, now Pope Leo XIV. The 69-year-old took his papal name before addressing thousands gathered at the basilica. Applause broke out when Father Nathaniel Glenn announced the new pontiff, connecting the event to the late Pope Francis. The election was met with enthusiasm and cheers from the local Catholic community.

stories.headline: Trump Pulls U.S. Attorney Pick as Support Flags
stories.summary: U.S. Senator Ed Martin faced opposition as the Biden administration pursued prosecution against the Capitol rioters of January 6, 2021. Despite Martin's nomination for U.S. attorney, his controversial views and Biden administration decisions led to the nomination being pulled amid political controversy and legal battles over the Jan. 6 events.

stories.headline: U.S. and U.K. Set Trade Plan, But Some Levies Will Be Kept
stories.summary: President Trump and the United Kingdom announced plans to strengthen trade ties post-Brexit by working towards a new trade agreement that would bring Britain closer to the U.S. despite retaining some tariffs on certain products to protect domestic industries. Both sides expressed commitment to cooperation, although specific details remain under negotiation with some divisions over tariffs and product lists.

stories.headline: An American Pope
stories.summary: Robert Francis Prevost was elected as Pope Leo XIV, the 267th pope of the Roman Catholic Church and the first American pope. His election followed a historic voting process amidst a global Catholic community's excitement. Pope Leo XIV shares a commitment to helping the poor and migrants and faces challenges addressing church divisions and opposition from conservative forces within the clergy.

stories.headline: Newark Panic: Chain of Errors At Travel Hub
stories.summary: A recent air traffic control failure at Newark Liberty International Airport caused major disruptions and near crashes due to miscommunications and equipment issues. The incident raised concerns about system reliability and operator training as flights were delayed and passengers faced long wait times. Investigations are ongoing to address the systemic failures highlighted by the event.

stories.headline: Ambassador encouraged by Trump-Carney conversation
stories.summary: Michigan's Pete Hoekstra, U.S. ambassador to Canada, expressed optimism following a constructive meeting between President Donald Trump and Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney. Hoekstra highlighted the friendship and partnership between the two nations and noted positive discussions that may improve diplomatic relations amidst previous trade tensions.

stories.headline: Judge declares mistrial in police officer's murder trial
stories.summary: The murder trial for the Grand Rapids police officer who killed Patrick Lyoya ended in a hung jury, with a mistrial declared after the jury deadlocked on second-degree murder charges. The officer, Christopher Schurr, was charged but the future of the case remains uncertain as the prosecutor decides on next steps. The trial involved tensions related to recent police shootings and protests.

stories.headline: Ford blames Trump tariffs for price increases on three models
stories.summary: Ford Motor Co. announced that prices for three of its popular vehicles will rise due to tariffs instituted by President Donald Trump, potentially increasing costs by up to $2,000 per vehicle. The affected models include the Mustang Mach-E, F-150 pickup, and Bronco Sport, which are assembled in Mexico. Ford anticipates a $2.5 billion cost impact from tariffs and is attempting to offset these through other pricing and efficiency measures.

stories.headline: DA POPE!
stories.summary: Chicagoan Robert Prevost, known to many on the South Side as 'Father Bob' and now to millions as Pope Leo XIV, becomes the first American pontiff. He appeared Thursday on the central balcony of St. Peter's Basilica for the first time after being elected pope.

stories.headline: Webber: Trump has been 'an assault on justice'
stories.summary: Santa Fe Mayor Alan Webber criticized President Donald Trump in a State of the City address, calling his first 100 days 'an assault on justice.' Webber expressed his commitment to immigrant rights, environmental sustainability, and progressive policies. While declining to confirm if he will seek reelection, Webber emphasized his dedication to the city's future and mission.

stories.headline: The American pope
stories.summary: Robert Francis Prevost, now known as Pope Leo XIV, made his first public appearance at St. Peter's Basilica. The U.S.-born leader of the Catholic Church brought surprise and joy to Chicago, Peru, and beyond, as the faithful expressed excitement over his unexpected election as the 267th pope of the Roman Catholic Church.

stories.headline: ACLU sues New Mexico prisons
stories.summary: The ACLU has filed a lawsuit against the New Mexico Corrections Department over its program that equates solitary confinement to torture. The state agency denies that inmates are being held in isolation, sparking a legal challenge on behalf of prisoners' rights.

stories.headline: Dunleavy says he'll veto education bill unless his policies are approved
stories.summary: Alaska Governor Mike Dunleavy announced he will veto a bipartisan education bill unless the Legislature also approves his policies tied to education funding. The bill includes a $177 million school funding increase and other education measures. Dunleavy told school superintendents he will reduce school funding if his veto is overridden. Education Commissioner Deena Bishop and Dunleavy emphasized lawmakers must approve incentive grants and other education priorities with the bill.

stories.headline: Judge rejects bid to halt state's bear-killing program
stories.summary: An Anchorage Superior Court judge denied a request to strike down a controversial state-sponsored predator control program that has so far killed 180 bears in Southwest Alaska. The judge ruled the program authorized last year is lawful, despite concerns raised over its legality and the environmental impact. The Alaska Department of Fish and Game had sought to halt the program but the state's emergency order allowing it stands pending further review.

stories.headline: White House revamp of US air traffic control system will cost 'lots of billions'
stories.summary: The Trump administration on Thursday proposed a multibillion-dollar overhaul of the U.S. air traffic control system, spotlighting the outdated network blamed for recent deadly plane crashes and technical failures. The current system still relies on floppy disks and replacement parts sourced from eBay. The plan calls for six new air traffic control centers with modern technology and emphasizes upgrades over the next three decades to ensure safer skies.

stories.headline: Robert Prevost becomes first pope from US
stories.summary: Chicago-born Catholic cardinal Robert Prevost was elected as Pope Leo XIV, becoming the first U.S. pope in history. Prevost, 69, a member of the Augustinian religious order, succeeded Pope Francis. His election marks a significant moment for the Catholic Church amid global turmoil and conflict. In his first words as pope, he urged peace and emphasized dialogue and missionary evangelization.

stories.headline: Leo XIV elected to succeed Francis as pontiff
stories.summary: The conclave of 267 cardinals elected Leo XIV as the new pope, the first American to hold the position, following Pope Francis. The election cheered thousands worldwide. The cardinals secluded themselves in the Vatican's Room of Tears before choosing the new leader for the 1.4 billion Roman Catholics. Leo XIV greeted the crowd with a message of peace.

stories.headline: Tigers legend Chet Lemon dies at 70
stories.summary: Chet Lemon, a celebrated legend of the Detroit Tigers baseball team, has died at the age of 70. His contributions to the sport and lasting legacy in Detroit baseball are remembered by fans and the community.

stories.headline: Detroit Catholics praise new pope; he once was a student in Michigan school
stories.summary: Catholics in metropolitan Detroit express pride and hope for Pope Leo XIV, who once studied in Michigan. They welcome his legacy of caring for marginalized communities and anticipate improvements in how the Vatican addresses sexual abuse concerns. His roots in Michigan add a personal connection for local faithful.

stories.headline: An American is selected as pope
stories.summary: Cardinal Robert Prevost, now Pope Leo XIV, becomes the first pope from the United States, ushering in a new era for the Catholic Church. The decision, marked by white smoke from the Sistine Chapel, was considered a surprise choice. Born in Chicago, Leo XIV attended Villanova University and the Catholic Theological Union in Chicago.

stories.headline: Tampa Bay Catholics express happiness
stories.summary: Tampa Bay Catholics and Bishop Gregory Parkes of the Diocese of Saint Petersburg are optimistic and supportive following the election of Robert Prevost as the new pope. Many gathered at St. Petersburg Catholic High School to pray and celebrate the historic news, hoping for peace and unity under the new leadership.

stories.headline: POPE LEO XIV
stories.summary: Robert Prevost has been elected as the first pontiff from the United States in the history of the Catholic Church. Taking the name Leo XIV, the 69-year-old member of the Augustinian religious order emphasized a message of peace and dialogue during his first address. Prevost, previously a missionary and archbishop in Peru, represents a historic shift for the papacy.

stories.headline: 'Legal morphine' will stay on Florida shelves as lawmakers fail to act
stories.summary: Despite concerns from researchers about the prevalence of 7-hydroxymitragynine products, lawmakers in Florida have not taken action to regulate or ban these substances. A proposal to remove these products from the market was stalled until 2026, leaving them available in gas stations and smoke shops. Researchers warn of potential health risks while consumer access remains.

stories.headline: A USF student lost his visa over protests
stories.summary: Joseph Charry, a Colombian national and former University of South Florida student, had his visa revoked after participating in pro-Palestine demonstrations. His case highlights a broader national issue involving thousands of international students facing repercussions due to involvement in protests and activism, causing uncertainty and disruption in their education and lives.

stories.headline: Trump-U.K. deal leaves questions
stories.summary: Economists remain skeptical about the value of the trade pact between the United States and the United Kingdom launched last month by President Trump. The deal marked a first of its kind sweeping global trade agreement but has raised uncertainties due to its impact on tariffs, exports, and overall economic benefits.

stories.headline: Unorthodox pick for surgeon general
stories.summary: President Trump's nominee for surgeon general is Dr. Casey Means, a holistic medicine doctor and wellness influencer. Her appointment marks a departure from traditional choices and highlights the administration's focus on alternative medicine and health policies. The nomination has sparked debates about the role of holistic health in federal policy.

stories.headline: Francis saw American as heir apparent
stories.summary: Robert Prevost, who had a career ministering in Peru, was anticipated by Pope Francis as a leading candidate to become the first U.S. pope. His election was seen as a continuation of Francis' vision for the church, and he took the papal name Leo XIV. This transition underscores Vatican City’s increasing international scope and influence.

stories.headline: Like L.A., a pontiff with no borders
stories.summary: The faithful in Los Angeles celebrated the election of Cardinal Robert Francis Prevost as pope, excited by the fact that he has deep roots in multiple countries including the U.S. and Peru. This election marks the first time someone from the U.S. has been entrusted with the highly influential position of pope, highlighting the global nature of the Catholic Church.

stories.headline: First U.S. pope is chosen
stories.summary: Robert Francis Prevost, 69, of Chicago becomes the 267th pontiff and will be known as Leo XIV. He is the first pope from the United States, marking a historic moment for the Catholic Church. Prevost, a former missionary in Peru, was elected by the Vatican, bringing a new chapter to the church's global leadership.

stories.headline: Most in state support requiring proof of citizenship to vote
stories.summary: A new poll reveals that 71% of voters in California believe government ID showing proof of citizenship should be required to register to vote. The survey shows bipartisan support for tighter voting regulations. This highlights ongoing debates regarding voting rights and election integrity in the state.

stories.headline: Teachers in turmoil
stories.summary: Teachers are facing significant backlash over using students' preferred names and pronouns. This issue has intensified after a Florida teacher lost a job following a law banning the practice. Several Republican-led states have passed similar laws restricting use of preferred pronouns and names for transgender or nonbinary students. Schools face ongoing legal challenges as they navigate these requirements amid differing laws across states.

stories.headline: Movie tariff plan raises a number of questions
stories.summary: A new plan to impose tariffs on movies has generated widespread discussion and raised multiple issues about its implications for the film industry and consumers. Details of the plan are still emerging, prompting business analysts to seek clarity on the potential economic and creative impacts.

stories.headline: SpaceX site in Texas is now the city of Starbase
stories.summary: Residents in Cameron County, Texas, primarily composed of SpaceX employees, voted overwhelmingly to create a new city named Starbase. This new city comprises a 220,000-acre area near the SpaceX rocket launch site, which Elon Musk envisions as a key hub for future Mars missions. The decision was driven by the local community's efforts, with support from several newly elected officials connected to SpaceX and cooperation between municipal government and the company.

stories.headline: First Trump trade deal to be sealed with Britain
stories.summary: President Trump announced a trade deal opening the British market to American farm products, chemicals, and machinery, aiming to rebalance global trade. Britain agreed to eliminate certain non-tariff trade barriers and reduce tariffs on automobiles and steel. The deal is expected to generate $5 billion in opportunities for U.S. exporters and $6 billion in tariff revenue, marking a significant step in U.S.-Britain trade relations.

stories.headline: First American pope elected
stories.summary: The Catholic Church has elected Cardinal Robert Francis Prevost as Pope Leo XIV, marking the first time an American has ascended to the papacy. His election was hailed as a historic moment by officials and politicians, celebrating it as a great honor for the country and Catholics worldwide. Despite being on the progressive side of the theological spectrum, his exact views remain unclear.

stories.headline: DOGE data drive finds dozens of illegal voters
stories.summary: The Department of Justice's investigation into illegal voting has uncovered dozens of noncitizens who cast ballots in recent elections. The probe, conducted by the Department of Government Efficiency, has resulted in prosecutions including cases in Florida, New York, and Maryland. Officials highlight this as evidence of election integrity issues and are continuing efforts to identify and prosecute illegal votes.

stories.headline: Trump, Biden, U.S. Catholics celebrate red, white, Holy See
stories.summary: Both President Trump and other Americans across political lines have celebrated the historic election of Cardinal Prevost as Pope Leo XIV, the first American pope. This bipartisan support and enthusiasm indicate the significance of the event for Catholics and the nation. Social media and public figures are marking the occasion with pride and hope for meaningful leadership.

stories.headline: Schools that fought AI now use it for teaching
stories.summary: Samantha Gleisten and other educators are now employing artificial intelligence tools, including chatbots created by students, to enhance teaching in middle schools. Initially cautious about AI, teachers are now embracing it to refine lessons and support student learning, incorporating creative projects like AI-generated music and videos. This shift demonstrates how technology is redefining education and pedagogy in the modern classroom.

stories.headline: Cardinal Prevost becomes Leo XIV, calls for peace, unity
stories.summary: Pope Leo XIV, formerly Cardinal Robert Francis Prevost, called for peace and unity in his inaugural address. He expressed gratitude towards his predecessor Pope Francis and emphasized the role of the Church as a missionary institution. His emotional and heartfelt address resonated with many, setting a tone of hope and reconciliation for his papacy.

stories.headline: Robert Prevost, first pope from US, takes name Leo XIV
stories.summary: Catholic cardinals in a historic conclave elected Robert Prevost as the first U.S. pope, taking the regnal name Leo XIV. Prevost, a 69-year-old member of the Augustinian religious order, succeeds Francis and emphasizes a message of peace and missionary evangelization. He wears the traditional red cape and trappings of the papacy and has suggested a continuity with past pontiffs while signaling a strong line of outreach and dialogue. He advocates for finding common ground among religions and urges openness and dialogue with different communities.

stories.headline: India, Pakistan trade fire and accusations
stories.summary: India fired attack drones into Pakistan, killing at least two civilians, according to Pakistani military sources. India accuses Pakistan of attempting attacks, while tensions escalated between the two nuclear-armed rivals following this recent cross-border conflict.

stories.headline: Council to interview new candidate
stories.summary: The Decatur City Council will interview one of five additional applicants for the reopened planning director position next week on the recommendation of Human Resources Director Richelle Sandlin. The council plans to interview Clifford Cross, director of Economic Development, Planning and Zoning in Belleville, Illinois. Sandlin selected Cross as the only candidate in this latest group because he is "very qualified and highly motivated." Cross has 25 years of experience in planning across multiple states and currently is director of community development in Kankakee, Illinois.

stories.headline: 40 teams set to compete
stories.summary: The Decatur Morgan Hospital Foundation Dragon Boat Race & Festival is set to kick off Saturday morning, with 40 competing teams expected to raise a combined total of at least $100,000 for the hospital. The event, which began 12 years ago, includes a drum ceremony and a Japanese drumming routine. Despite rain expected later, the festival promises exciting events including the Iron Ore Challenge and award ceremonies later in the day. The day-long festivities will also feature various sponsors and community involvement.

stories.headline: Kiwanis’ fundraiser sets record
stories.summary: The Decatur Kiwanis Club set a fundraising record with its Pancake Day event for the second year in a row, raising a total of $150,421. They surpassed the previous record by more than $15,000. The fundraiser is a passionate effort to support many organizations in the community, with the total amount announced at a meeting honoring funding recipients. After expenses, over $113,560 was distributed to these groups. The club plans to give $34,500 to fund the City of Decatur Parks and Recreation Department and continues to select impactful projects for support.

stories.headline: Safety a priority after numerous hit and runs
stories.summary: Athens has seen a significant increase in hit-and-run incidents over the past year, whether involving vehicles versus vehicles or vehicles versus pedestrians. Athens Mayor Ronnie Marks and local authorities are working to safeguard the large amount of foot traffic in the city to improve safety and reduce accidents.

stories.headline: Tanner Elementary getting a makeover
stories.summary: Tanner Elementary School is receiving a $2.1 million overhaul of its interior over the summer to make the environment lighter, brighter, and more conducive for returning students' learning. This renovation aims to enhance the school's facilities ahead of the new academic year.

stories.headline: EU prepares to retaliate on tariffs
stories.summary: The European Union published a list of U.S. imports that it would target with retaliatory duties if no solution is found to end U.S. President Donald Trump's tariff war, which could include aircraft maker Boeing. The move is part of ongoing trade tensions between the U.S. and EU regarding tariffs and trade duties.

stories.headline: CEO of 1-800-Flowers Decides to ‘Fire Myself’
stories.summary: Jim McCann, founder of 1-800-Flowers.com, decided to step down from his CEO role after over 50 years in the flower delivery business, citing a desire to move on and keep the company innovative. The transition aims to ensure the company remains competitive and responsive to market changes, with McCann remaining active in related initiatives.

stories.headline: Their Fridge Obsession Is a Recipe for Discontent
stories.summary: The article explores a 49-year-old healthcare worker's experience with the obsession over organizing and stocking refrigerators, highlighting how such habits reflect broader discontent and the quest for control in daily life. The story mixes practical fridge tips and psychological insight into everyday behaviors.

stories.headline: Trump Unveils Framework For a Trade Deal With U.K.
stories.summary: President Trump announced his administration's new trade framework with the U.K., aiming to establish a series of agreements following U.S. tariffs. The deal seeks to benefit sectors like automobiles and steel but faces limits and challenges in fully removing tariffs. The pact underscores ongoing efforts in U.S.-U.K. trade relations amid global economic tensions.

stories.headline: Toys, Tools Blocked By Tariff Chaos
stories.summary: Importers are canceling orders while Chinese factories are cutting staff and offloading goods due to uncertainty caused by tariffs and trade disputes. Retailers report disrupted supply chains with significant impacts in regions such as China and the U.S., affecting holiday-themed products and other goods as the trade tensions persist.

stories.headline: A Fractured Church Seeks Steady Leader
stories.summary: Catholic cardinals elected Robert Prevost, a Chicagoan, as the first American pope in nearly two millennia, hoping for leadership to navigate internal church divisions and global challenges. Prevost's background includes being a close aide to the late Pope Francis, with emphasis on dialogue and practical solutions to modern church issues.

stories.headline: First Pope From U.S. Elected
stories.summary: The Roman Catholic Church has elected its first pope from the U.S., Chicago-born Cardinal Robert Francis Prevost, who served in Peru and the Vatican. He becomes Pope Leo XIV, marking a historic event as he addresses immigration and aims to unify the Catholic Church amid ideological divisions.

stories.headline: Abundant Life shooter’s father arrested
stories.summary: Jeffrey Rupnow, the father of the Abundant Life shooter, was arrested by Madison police on felony charges related to contributing to the delinquency of a child and possession of a dangerous weapon. The charges stem from an incident where the shooter fatally shot a fellow student and injured others at a Christian school in Madison. Investigation revealed Rupnow may have had a role in providing firearms or access, marking significant legal developments in the tragic case.

stories.headline: Milwaukee Catholics react with joy after pope announcement
stories.summary: Milwaukee-area Catholics expressed joy and excitement following the election of Pope Leo XIV, the first North American pope. Cardinal Robert Prevost, newly named as Pope Leo XIV, was celebrated by the community, highlighting the historic and emotional significance of the event for local believers.

stories.headline: 'Habemus papam': New pope elected
stories.summary: Cardinal Robert Prevost has been elected as Pope Leo XIV, succeeding Pope Francis. The announcement took place after a conclave at the Vatican, marking the emergence of a new leader for the world's 1.4 billion Roman Catholics. Cardinal Prevost is noted as the first North American pope and the first from the United States, considered a surprising and historic choice.

stories.headline: Briggs: Fireworks season will be quieter, thanks to tariffs
stories.summary: Briggs discusses the impact of tariffs on the upcoming fireworks season, suggesting that the season will be quieter than usual. Tariffs have affected supply and availability, influencing how the fireworks industry and consumers are preparing for celebrations.

stories.headline: Will tariffs hurt Indiana's long trade relationship with Canada?
stories.summary: Concerns arise following President Donald Trump's wide-ranging tariffs on several countries including Canada. Indiana Chamber survey of nearly 200 state business leaders reveals apprehensions about the tariffs and retaliatory actions harming Indiana's long-standing trade relationship with Canada.

stories.headline: Morales is accused of violating election law in IN
stories.summary: Indiana Secretary of State Diego Morales faces accusations of violating state election laws through his new reelection campaign video. The video allegedly contained footage from an official visit to Marion County's secured Election Service Center, blending campaign and official activities, which is against state law.

stories.headline: 'Habemus papam': New pope elected
stories.summary: Cardinal Robert Prevost has been selected as Pope Leo XIV, succeeding Francis as pontiff. This marks the first time a pope from the United States has been elected. The announcement was made at the Vatican with great fanfare, marking a historic moment for the Roman Catholic Church.

stories.headline: President wants higher taxes on the wealthy in budget bill
stories.summary: President Donald Trump is proposing higher taxes on wealthy individuals, targeting those earning more than $5 million per year. The move aims to address fiscal issues and redistribute wealth, although it contrasts with the earlier tax cuts for corporations and individuals from 2017. This proposal has sparked debate among lawmakers and the public.

stories.headline: U.S., Britain reach trade pact in first agreement on tariffs
stories.summary: President Donald Trump and British officials have struck an agreement easing economic restrictions on ethanol, beef, and other products, facilitating bilateral trade. This deal marks the first synergy between the two nations on tariffs and is expected to boost economic collaboration and remove barriers that hinder trade growth.

stories.headline: Martin out as U.S. attorney, to be replaced by Fox host
stories.summary: President Donald Trump has named Fox News host Jeanne Pirro to replace U.S. attorney for D.C., Kellye Martin. This move sparked controversy due to Pirro's background as a conservative commentator rather than a traditional legal professional. Pirro is expected to oversee significant legal priorities under the new administration.

stories.headline: Bells toll in U.S. as faithful grasp the 'unbelievable'
stories.summary: In the U.S., John McGreevy, a prominent historian of Catholicism, reacts with amazement to the election of Robert Prevost as the first American pope, describing the event as 'unbelievable.' The election is seen as a source of joy and surprise, with millions of U.S. Catholics celebrating this historic moment in the papacy.

stories.headline: Path to papacy wound through Peru, Vatican
stories.summary: Robert Prevost's election as Pope Leo XIV symbolizes a historic moment for American popes, following his experiences ministering in Peru to marginalized communities. His journey highlights the influence of global and local connections on his papacy, marking a significant transition within the Catholic Church's hierarchy.

stories.headline: First American pope is chosen
stories.summary: Robert Prevost, a Chicago native, has been elected Pope Leo XIV, marking the first American pope. The election signifies a major change as Leo XIV breaks the longstanding taboo of electing a pope from Oceania and Latin America, signaling a shift in power away from Europe. His election is viewed as a nod to the social teachings of the Church and reflects a connection with the Global South and marginalized communities.

stories.headline: '84 Tigers hero brought dynamic defense, personality
stories.summary: Chet Lemon, a celebrated Detroit Tigers outfielder and key member of the 1984 championship team, passed away at 70. Remembered for his defensive skill and charismatic presence on the field, Lemon left a lasting impact on teammates and fans alike.

stories.headline: Michigan Catholics take pride in Leo's connection
stories.summary: Michigan Catholics celebrated the election of Leo XIV, proud of his local connections as he is the first US-born pope. The cardinal and new pope spent time in west Michigan as a minor seminarian and is recognized for his religious and leadership roles.

stories.headline: Will Schurr be retried after mistrial?
stories.summary: Kent County’s top prosecutor will decide whether to retry former Grand Rapids police officer Christopher Schurr for second-degree murder after a mistrial was declared in the fatal shooting of Patrick Lyoya following a traffic stop in 2022. The case faces challenges due to media attention and other factors, delaying the decision on the next legal steps.

stories.headline: First American pope has ties to west Mich.
stories.summary: Leo XIV, the first American pope, who previously served as a priest and missionary, has ascended to the papacy. The new pope has connections to west Michigan, having attended a minor seminary for high school there. His election marks a significant event with ties to regional Catholic communities.

stories.headline: State Supreme Court upholds ban on high-capacity gun magazines
stories.summary: The Washington Supreme Court upheld the state's ban on large-capacity gun magazines, ruling that the state can regulate magazines holding more than 10 bullets without violating the Constitution. The decision overturns a lower-court ruling and allows the continued possession and sale of high-capacity magazines to be restricted in Washington. The ruling emphasizes the state's authority to regulate firearms for self-defense and public safety.

stories.headline: From Chicago, a priest's global route to papacy
stories.summary: Robert Francis Prevost, newly elected as Pope Leo XIV, was chosen from Chicago as the 267th pope of the Roman Catholic Church and is the first U.S. pope. The article outlines his journey from priesthood to being elected by the cardinals, highlighting his commitment to service, particularly to the poor and migrants, and his leadership within the Augustinian order. The election signals a shift to focus on caring for the marginalized and ministering to those in need.

stories.headline: A MESSAGE OF 'DIALOGUE AND LOVE'
stories.summary: Robert Prevost, an American Cardinal and former leader of the Augustinian order who ministered in Peru, has been elected as the 267th pope of the Roman Catholic Church, taking the name Leo XIV. Prevost's election marks a historic moment as he is the first U.S.-born pope. His message emphasizes peace, dialogue, missionary evangelization, and a commitment to serving the poor and migrants, calling for simplicity and devotion in church leadership.

stories.headline: Gates Foundation: 20-year countdown
stories.summary: The Gates Foundation, founded by Bill Gates, has announced its plan to give away nearly Bill Gates' entire fortune of about $107 billion and close the foundation by 2045. The foundation has contributed billions to global health efforts and aims to ultimately disburse more than $200 billion. This move reflects Gates' dedication to philanthropy and his desire to solve urgent global problems through the foundation's work.

stories.headline: Wabanaki group restores Swanville farm as food hub
stories.summary: Niweškok, a food sovereignty organization, recently acquired a 245-acre farm in Swanville to revitalize traditional crops and land management practices, demonstrating stewardship to ancestral lands in the Penobscot Bay region. The group has invested over $1.8 million to purchase the farm, aiming to create a sustainable food hub that preserves cultural traditions and boosts economic resilience. This initiative reflects a commitment to long-term food sovereignty and community empowerment for generations to come.

stories.headline: Collins: Canadian students facing 'excessive' scrutiny coming into Maine
stories.summary: Senator Susan Collins has raised concerns about Canadian students attending school in Aroostook County who are being subjected to 'excessive' security screening and questioning at the northern border. Collins, a Republican and chair of the Senate Appropriations Committee, addressed these issues during a budget hearing with Department of Homeland Security officials. She also questioned the funding for marijuana growing operations in Maine allegedly linked to transnational Chinese gangs.

stories.headline: Transgender rights debate draws hundreds to Augusta
stories.summary: A series of emotional public hearings in Augusta respond to a flurry of bills aimed at restricting transgender athletes' participation in girls' sports and banning gender identity protections in Maine’s Human Rights Act. The debate focuses on whether school districts can require students to use restrooms corresponding to their sex assigned at birth. The hearings have attracted significant attention amid scrutiny over transgender student rights, with a high school junior testifying about her experience.

stories.headline: Cardinal Robert Prevost will be 1st American pope
stories.summary: Cardinal Robert Prevost has become the first American pope in the Catholic Church’s 2,000-year history. He will be known as Pope Leo XIV. Several people from Maine witnessed the selection as white smoke rose in Vatican City, signaling the choice. Prevost succeeds Pope Francis as the leader of the Roman Catholic Church. The announcement has received attention from people both locally and abroad.

stories.headline: 'I'm thrilled with his election'
stories.summary: Bishop Zubik and other Catholics in the area express joy and excitement over the election of Cardinal Robert Prevost as Pope Leo XIV. They highlight his deep roots in mission work and see his election as historic and inspiring for the local Catholic community and beyond. Speculation about the conclave was widespread, with many hopefuls considered before Prevost was chosen.

stories.headline: Pope Leo XIV overcomes a taboo against a U.S. pontiff
stories.summary: Robert Prevost broke a longstanding taboo against American popes by becoming the 267th pontiff of the Catholic Church. Known as Robert Leo XIV, the Chicago native and former missionary in Peru succeeds Pope Francis and stands as a symbol of changing traditions within the Vatican, bringing new hope and global connections to his papacy.

stories.headline: First American Pope
stories.summary: Catholic cardinals elected Robert Prevost, a Chicago-born missionary and Villanova graduate, as Pope Leo XIV, succeeding Pope Francis as the leader of the world's 1.4 billion Catholics. He is the first American pope and known for his message of peace and evangelization, building bridges and establishing dialogue to meet the needs of charity and presence in the church.

stories.headline: The American Pope redefining leadership for the world
stories.summary: An opinion piece reflecting on the newly elected Pope Leo XIV, who is American-born Robert Francis Prevost. The article highlights his background as a bilingual, culturally diverse leader with experience in Latin America and his compassion for immigrants and the poor. It emphasizes the potential positive impact of his leadership on the Catholic Church globally and within his home state in California, positioning him as a unifying spiritual figure in a polarized environment.

stories.headline: Trump v. law firms: Using power on potential court foes
stories.summary: President Donald Trump has used his position to push against a law firm in February by ordering a review of government contracts linked to Covington & Burling, after allegations that a lawyer helped special prosecutors targeting him. Security clearances for certain lawyers have been suspended and the administration is reviewing responsibilities in the judicial process. Experts suggest these moves aim to discourage law firms from representing clients opposing Trump, raising concerns about fairness in legal battles.

stories.headline: Trump touts ‘full’ US-UK trade pact in boost for Starmer after weeks of talks
stories.summary: President Donald Trump announced a comprehensive trade agreement between the U.S. and the U.K., marking the first of his promised deals with various countries worldwide. Trump described the agreement as "exciting" for both nations, expressing honor in securing the deal with the United Kingdom, which is seen as a major announcement following weeks of negotiation.

stories.headline: Vatican announces first US pope: Leo XIV
stories.summary: Cardinal Robert Francis Prevost of the United States has been elected the new pope and has chosen the name Pope Leo XIV. He is the first U.S. and second American pope, succeeding Pope Francis, who was from Argentina. Leo XIV, formerly Cardinal Prevost, is 69 years old and the Archbishop of Peru. He is the first American pope and the first elected after the College of Cardinals avoided elevating U.S. clergy to leadership roles due to political considerations. His election marks a significant global influence for the church and he also holds dual citizenship with Peru and the United States.

stories.headline: How much can walking boost your brain? Here’s what consistent movement triggers
stories.summary: Research indicates that walking briskly for two hours a week can improve a person's mood, reduce symptoms of stress and depression, and enhance brain health. Walking, like other exercises, releases dopamine and other feel-good chemicals. Health experts say walking helps people lose weight, reduce chronic conditions, and manage diseases like diabetes. Dr. Dante Durand, medical officer at Jackson Behavioral Health Hospital, highlights the benefits of walking combined with good brain chemicals.

stories.headline: Proposed sales-tax cut caught in the middle as DeSantis and Florida House speaker feud
stories.summary: Florida Republican Governor Ron DeSantis opposed a Florida House plan to cut state sales taxes. The disagreement took place during a Tampa news conference where both sides voiced differing views on the state's fiscal health. DeSantis advocated for a quick legislative response for tax cuts, whereas the House speaker disagreed, leading to a feud amid ongoing negotiations over the state budget.

stories.headline: Second body cam video deleted after George Pino boat crash, FWC says
stories.summary: The Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission confirmed that body camera footage of a second officer at the scene of the George Pino boat crash, which killed a teenage girl, was deleted. The footage was taken from officers watching over the boat operator, George Pino. The deletion occurred after the officer mislabelled his body camera footage, causing it to be deleted after 90 days, violating FWC's policy that body camera footage must be retained during criminal investigations. The officer involved was Keith Hernandez.

stories.headline: Leo XIV becomes first pope from U.S.
stories.summary: Robert Francis Prevost was elected the 267th pope of the Roman Catholic Church, becoming the first pope from the United States. His election defies the long-standing belief that global church leaders wouldn't select a pope from a superpower nation with strong global influence. Prevost, a 69-year-old Chicago-born polyglot, emphasized the need to build bridges and unity within the church. The election followed several rounds of voting over more than 24 hours and was the result of a conclave attended by a record 133 cardinals.

stories.headline: Drake softball falls in Missouri Valley Conference quarterfinals
stories.summary: The Drake University softball team was defeated in the Missouri Valley Conference quarterfinals. The loss ends their run in the conference tournament and marks a significant moment for the team this season.

stories.headline: Trump’s cuts forcing nonprofits to change strategies to survive
stories.summary: Julie Green Fugenschuh, leader of Project IOWA, highlights how cuts to government funding are forcing nonprofits to adapt their strategies for survival. The nonprofit focuses on training and supporting job seekers at the Franklin Junior High School in Des Moines, emphasizing collaborations and efficient resource use to meet increasing demands. Fugenschuh notes the ongoing economic uncertainty and funding challenges but remains committed to sustaining impactful services.

stories.headline: Property tax overhaul proposal progresses
stories.summary: Senate lawmakers are advancing a new version of legislation to overhaul Iowa's property tax system, aiming to provide a 25% discount on the value of houses up to $125,000. The Senate Ways and Means Committee pushed forward Senate Study Bill 1227 with this amendment. The House companion measure has not yet received its first legislative consideration, and it remains uncertain whether the House will agree to the proposed changes before the 2025 legislative session ends. Lawmakers express hope but also frustration with the slow progress of property tax reform.

stories.headline: 'Habemus papam': New pope elected
stories.summary: Cardinal Robert Francis Prevost has been elected as Pope Leo XIV, becoming the first pope from the United States and the 267th pope in history. The election took place after the cardinals convened in the Sistine Chapel in Rome, with the announcement marked by the traditional white smoke. This new era for the Catholic Church is seen as historic, with Pope Leo XIV greeting the crowd with 'Peace be with you all.'

stories.headline: 'Saint of the North' in Peru tended to poor
stories.summary: Robert F. Prevost, now Pope Leo XIV, was known in Peru as a saintly missionary who helped the poor by providing oxygen production plants during the COVID-19 pandemic. He was actively helping poor communities and working for the church's Caritas nonprofit in Peru before his election as pope. This highlights his humanitarian efforts and history as the first Latin American open pope.

stories.headline: An American Pope
stories.summary: Cardinal Robert F. Prevost, an Augustinian and a Villanova alumnus, has been elected as Pope Leo XIV, succeeding the late Pope Francis. He is the first US-born pope and the first Augustinian to become pope. Prevost is the first alumnus from Villanova University to hold this title. His installation ceremony took place with congratulations from world leaders, including Presidents Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin.

stories.headline: Fewer drinkers at music venues weakens revenue
stories.summary: Local venues and music operators in Twin Cities are facing reduced revenue due to a decline in drinking, aggravated by ongoing challenges like the COVID-19 pandemic and competition from events such as the Minneapolis Music Summit. With declining sales, local businesses are seeking alternative revenue streams to cope with the drop in traditional alcohol sales at music venues.

stories.headline: Talon Metals touts ‘exceptional’ find
stories.summary: Talon Metals announced an exceptional mineral discovery near Aitkin County, Minnesota, where exploratory drilling uncovered minerals with the highest concentration of nickel yet identified by the company. The findings extend across 292 holes over four years, enhancing prospects for supplying valuable metals like nickel, copper, gold, and platinum group metals for electric vehicle batteries.

stories.headline: A first: Pope from U.S.
stories.summary: Robert Prevost has made history by becoming the first pope from the United States, known as Pope Leo XIV. Previously a missionary in Peru, Prevost overcame taboos to lead the Catholic Church as the son of a global superpower. His election symbolizes a new chapter for the Church, emphasizing social teachings, continuity with Pope Francis' reforms, and addressing the challenges of the modern global south.

stories.headline: Tennessee Tech provost picked as first woman to lead UTC
stories.summary: Lori Mann Bruce has been tapped as the next chancellor of the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga, pending approval. She will be the first woman to hold this role in the university's 138-year history. Bruce, who currently serves as the Tennessee Tech provost, follows a national search succeeding interim Chancellor Robert Dooley.

stories.headline: An American pope
stories.summary: Robert Francis Prevost was elected the 267th pope of the Roman Catholic Church, becoming the first pope from the United States. Taking the name Pope Leo XIV, he was chosen after the usual secretive and smoke signal process at the Vatican. He is committed to helping the poor and migrants, and belongs to the order of Augustinians who devote themselves to ministry.

stories.headline: Experts weigh in on gang tattoos
stories.summary: President Donald Trump's claim that Kilmar Abrego Garcia, mistakenly deported to El Salvador, is a member of the MS-13 gang based on tattoos on his knuckles is questioned by experts. The tattoos featured letters and numbers but are common and may not clearly signify MS-13 membership. Experts say the tattoos don't definitively indicate gang membership and many are open to interpretation.

stories.headline: School board passes budget that cuts jobs
stories.summary: The Hamilton County school board passed a balanced budget with an 8-3 vote that removes half a principal's position at every school, reduces benchmarking testing, and cuts $5.3 million from the central office. The final budget results in a $16.2 million deficit due to lower-than-expected local tax revenues and rising costs, particularly in health care. Majority Democrats opposed passing the budget but it was approved despite concerns it does not provide additional funds to the district's needs.

stories.headline: Execs blunt about Sanders' draft slide
stories.summary: NFL team officials respond to questions raised by NFL Draft analysts about the selection of college players and cultural biases involved in the draft process, sparking conversations about transparency and fairness in sports.

stories.headline: Reeves gets real about toll of 'Wick'
stories.summary: Actor, director, and star Chad Stahelski speaks candidly about the physical and emotional demands of working on the 'Wick' franchise in a new documentary titled 'Wick Is Pain'.

stories.headline: Trump scores big trade agreement with United Kingdom
stories.summary: President Donald Trump successfully negotiated a trade agreement with the United Kingdom after pausing his reciprocal tariffs on April 2 and resuming them briefly before pausing again. The deal involves larger trade between the U.S. and UK, with potential impacts on economic markets and concerns about tariffs, especially involving China. Despite some economic uncertainty, markets responded positively to the news.

stories.headline: Prevost a surprise: Chicago native's path to the papacy
stories.summary: Robert Francis Prevost, a Chicago native, was unexpectedly elected Pope Leo XIV, succeeding Pope Francis who died recently. Prevost's selection surprised many as he was not seen as a leading contender. He has been ordained since 1981 and belongs to the Order of Saint Augustine. His election marks the first time the pope is from the United States.

stories.headline: Emotions flow as white smoke rises from Vatican
stories.summary: After the election of Cardinal Robert Francis Prevost as Pope Leo XIV, crowds cheered and celebrated at the Vatican. The room known as the Room of Tears saw an emotional response as the new pope stepped onto the balcony and announced the historic words, "Habemus papam" (we have a pope).

stories.headline: Catholic Church makes history: POPE LEO XIV FIRST FROM U.S.
stories.summary: Cardinal Robert Francis Prevost was elected as Pope Leo XIV, making history as the first pope from the United States. He emerged dramatically from the Sistine Chapel following a papal conclave and greeted the crowd, marking a historic moment in the 1.4 billion-member Roman Catholic Church.

stories.headline: State representative discusses case of uploaded photos
stories.summary: A Kentucky state representative, Rep. Samara Heavrin, addresses concerns about social media photos posted on a pornography website without victims' consent. These photos involve potentially hundreds of victims, including a 29-year-old woman from Caneyville. Rep. Heavrin is actively working to help victims and prevent future incidents by raising awareness of this issue in the commonwealth.

stories.headline: Kentucky Republicans playing part in proposed Medicaid cuts
stories.summary: Kentucky Republicans are involved in the ongoing federal discussion about cuts to Medicaid, part of a potential $880 billion reduction in healthcare spending over 10 years. Members of the U.S. House from Kentucky, especially those from Medicaid-reliant districts such as the 5th Congressional District represented by Hal Rogers, are navigating the reconciliation budget bill. Newly appointed House Energy and Commerce Committee chair Rep. Brett Guthrie is responsible for shaping these Medicaid cuts with Republican leadership.

stories.headline: Vatican announces first US pope: Leo XIV
stories.summary: Cardinal Robert Prevost of the United States has been elected the new pope, choosing the name Leo XIV. He is the first US pope and second American pope overall. The conclave to elect him was prolonged with no decision on the first day, but he was announced after the second ballot. This marks a historic moment with the new pope addressing the crowd from St. Peter's Basilica in Vatican City.

stories.headline: State removes women from substance recovery center
stories.summary: The Kentucky Department of Corrections has removed 46 women under its care from a Richmond treatment center for substance use disorder after multiple complaints about the facility. The women were previously housed at Liberty Place Recovery Center for Women in Madison County, a halfway house used to integrate inmates into society after incarceration. Complaints include expired food, lack of contact with parole officers, and residency issues as part of a prison sentence. The state is investigating compliance and allegations at Liberty Place.

stories.headline: Chicago school board president talks cuts, uncertainty
stories.summary: Sean Harden, Chicago school board President, discussed with school principals the challenges of budget cuts and the impact on the upcoming school year. Despite financial difficulties, including a $529 million cash crunch, Harden aimed to maintain equitable resource allocation and transparency, emphasizing the need for community input and acknowledging the tough decisions ahead.

stories.headline: Chicago's pope
stories.summary: Robert Prevost was elected as the first American pontiff, taking the name Leo XIV, marking a historic moment for the Catholic Church, and bringing pride and joy to the faithful in Chicago. Prevost emphasized peace, dialogue, and missionary evangelization in his initial message as Pope.
